use: Used in Ayurvedic medicine for colds, cough, and flu. Also has religious significance in Hindu households.
waterNeeds: Moderate; water when top inch of soil feels dry
careTips: Pinch off flower buds to encourage leaf growth. Prune regularly to maintain bushy growth. Protect from frost.
storageTips: Dry leaves in shade and store in airtight container. Fresh leaves can be refrigerated for up to a week.
growthForm: Perennial herb growing to 30-60 cm tall
specification: Considered sacred in Hinduism. Different varieties include Krishna Tulsi (purple leaves) and Rama Tulsi (green leaves).

use: Used in traditional medicine for skin diseases, fever, and infections. Young leaves used in cooking. Oil used in cosmetics and as natural pesticide.
careTips: Tolerates poor soil. Fertilize minimally. Protect young plants from frost.
storageTips: Dry leaves in shade and store in airtight containers. Neem oil should be stored in dark bottles.
growthForm: Evergreen tree growing up to 15-20 meters
specification: Known as 'village pharmacy' due to its numerous medicinal properties. Can live for 150-200 years.

use: Rhizomes used as spice in cooking, in religious ceremonies, and for medicinal purposes like anti-inflammation and wound healing.
waterNeeds: High; keep soil consistently moist but not waterlogged
careTips: Plant in rich, well-draining soil. Mulch to retain moisture. Harvest when leaves turn yellow.
storageTips: Store fresh rhizomes in a cool, dark place or refrigerate. Dried powder in airtight containers.
growthForm: Perennial herb growing to 1 meter tall
specification: Contains curcumin, which gives it bright yellow color and medicinal properties. Grows best in temperatures between 20-30Â°C.

use: High in Vitamin C. Used in Ayurvedic medicine for digestion, diabetes, and immunity. Fruits eaten fresh or processed.
careTips: Prune after fruiting. Apply organic manure annually. Protect from strong winds.
storageTips: Fresh fruits last 1-2 weeks in refrigeration. Can be preserved in salt water or made into preserves.
growthForm: Deciduous tree growing up to 8-18 meters
specification: Extremely high vitamin C content - one fruit contains as much vitamin C as 2-3 oranges. Fruits are harvested in autumn.

use: Gel used for skin care, burns, and wounds. Also used in beverages and food products.
waterNeeds: Low; allow soil to dry completely between watering
sunlightNeeds: Bright indirect light to partial sun
careTips: Plant in well-draining soil. Repot when rootbound. Protect from frost.
storageTips: Fresh gel can be refrigerated for up to a week. Can be frozen in ice cube trays.
growthForm: Succulent with thick, fleshy leaves growing in a rosette
specification: Contains over 75 active compounds. Inner leaf gel is clear and soothing. Outer leaf contains aloin which has laxative properties.

use: Leaves used as flavoring in South Indian cuisine. Also used in folk medicine for digestive problems.
careTips: Fertilize every 2-3 months. Prune to maintain shape. May drop leaves in winter.
storageTips: Fresh leaves can be refrigerated for up to two weeks. Can be dried or frozen for longer storage.
growthForm: Small evergreen tree or shrub growing up to 4-6 meters
specification: Aromatic leaves with distinct curry-like fragrance. Seeds and bark also have medicinal properties.

use: Root used in Ayurveda as adaptogen for stress, anxiety, and improving energy levels.
careTips: Grows in poor soil. Space plants 60 cm apart. Protect from excessive moisture.
storageTips: Harvest roots after 1 year. Dry thoroughly and store in airtight containers.
growthForm: Erect shrub growing up to 1.5 meters tall
specification: Known as 'Indian Ginseng'. Berries can be used for seed propagation. Contains withanolides with medicinal properties.

use: Used in religious ceremonies, as garden ornamentals, and as companion plants to repel pests.
waterNeeds: Moderate; allow top soil to dry between watering
careTips: Deadhead spent flowers to encourage more blooms. Can be grown from seeds or cuttings.
storageTips: Flowers can be dried and used for garlands. Seeds can be collected when flowers dry on the plant.
growthForm: Annual herb growing up to 0.5-1 meter tall
specification: Widely used in Diwali and other Hindu ceremonies. Contains lutein which is beneficial for eye health.

use: Valued for its hard timber used in furniture making, carving, and construction.
careTips: Prune to maintain shape. Watch for pests like defoliators and borers.
storageTips: Not applicable for home storage as it's primarily grown for timber.
growthForm: Deciduous tree growing up to 25 meters tall
specification: Fast-growing species that also helps in preventing soil erosion. Wood has a distinctive grain pattern and reddish-brown color.

use: Used in cooking for its citrus flavor, in teas, and in essential oils for aromatherapy.
careTips: Divide clumps every 2-3 years. Cut back to 15 cm occasionally to promote fresh growth.
storageTips: Fresh stalks can be refrigerated for up to 3 weeks. Can be frozen or dried for longer storage.
growthForm: Perennial grass growing in clumps up to 1-1.5 meters tall
specification: Contains citral which gives it distinctive lemon scent. Also acts as natural mosquito repellent.

use: National flower of India. Used in religious ceremonies. Seeds, young leaves, and rhizomes eaten as food.
waterNeeds: Very high; aquatic plant that needs standing water
careTips: Plant in containers with no drainage holes filled with heavy clay soil. Water depth should be 15-30 cm above soil.
storageTips: Seeds can be dried and stored. Rhizomes can be harvested and stored like potatoes.
growthForm: Aquatic perennial with rhizomes anchored in mud
specification: Flowers and leaves are water-repellent due to the 'lotus effect'. All parts of the plant are used in Ayurvedic medicine.

use: Seeds used for oil and spice. Leaves used as vegetable. Oil cake used as animal feed and fertilizer.
waterNeeds: Moderate; sensitive to both drought and waterlogging
careTips: Sow directly in well-draining soil. Thin seedlings to 15 cm apart. Harvest when pods turn yellow.
storageTips: Store seeds in airtight containers in cool, dry place. Oil should be stored away from direct light.
growthForm: Annual herb growing up to 1-2 meters tall
specification: Cold-pressed mustard oil is commonly used in North Indian cooking. Also used in crop rotation for its bio-fumigation properties.

use: National tree of India with religious significance. Bark and roots used in traditional medicine.
careTips: Not suitable for home growing due to massive size. Young plants need protection from frost.
storageTips: Not applicable for home storage; primarily an outdoor specimen tree.
growthForm: Evergreen tree with aerial roots that can spread over hectares
specification: Can live for several hundred years. The Great Banyan in Howrah is over 250 years old and covers an area of 14,500 square meters.

use: Flowers used in religious ceremonies, perfumes, and garlands. Also used to flavor tea.
careTips: Regular pruning after flowering. Apply balanced fertilizer during growing season.
storageTips: Fresh flowers last only a few days. Can be dried or used to make potpourri.
growthForm: Evergreen vine or shrub growing up to 2-3 meters tall
specification: Flowers open at night and release strongest fragrance in evening. Several varieties grown in India include single and double-flowered forms.

use: Heartwood and oil used in perfumes, religious ceremonies, and carving. Has cooling properties in Ayurveda.
careTips: Requires host plants initially as it's semi-parasitic. Grows slowly and needs protection from frost.
storageTips: Heartwood can be stored indefinitely. Oil should be stored in dark glass bottles.
growthForm: Evergreen tree growing up to 12-15 meters tall
specification: Trees must be at least 30 years old before harvesting for quality heartwood. Protected species in India due to overexploitation.

use: Used in Ayurveda for improving memory, reducing anxiety, and treating epilepsy.
careTips: Grows well in shallow water or very moist soil. Can be grown indoors in containers with no drainage.
storageTips: Fresh leaves can be refrigerated briefly. Usually dried and stored in airtight containers for medicinal use.
growthForm: Creeping herb with small white flowers
specification: Contains bacosides which support cognitive function. Often confused with Centella asiatica, which is also called Brahmi in northern India.

use: Sacred tree in Buddhism and Hinduism. Bark, fruit, and leaves used in traditional medicine.
careTips: Not suitable for home growing due to massive size and invasive roots. Young plants need protection from frost.
storageTips: Not applicable for home storage; primarily an outdoor specimen tree.
growthForm: Deciduous tree growing up to 30 meters tall
specification: Distinctive heart-shaped leaves with long drip tips. Buddha is said to have attained enlightenment under this tree.

use: Fruit used in cooking and traditional medicine, particularly for diabetes management.
waterNeeds: Moderate; water when top inch of soil feels dry
careTips: Provide trellis for climbing. Add compost before planting. Harvest when fruits are still green.
storageTips: Fresh fruits can be refrigerated for up to a week. Can be blanched and frozen for longer storage.
growthForm: Annual climbing vine growing up to 5 meters long
specification: Contains charantin which helps lower blood glucose levels. Fruits become more bitter as they mature and turn orange.

use: Fruit used in religious offerings to Lord Shiva, in beverages, and for treating digestive disorders.
careTips: Prune to maintain shape. Fertilize annually. Protect young plants from frost.
storageTips: Fresh fruit can be stored up to 2 weeks. Pulp can be dried or made into preserves.
growthForm: Deciduous tree growing up to 12-15 meters tall
specification: Hard-shelled fruit with aromatic pulp. Slow-growing but can live for over 100 years.

use: Flowers used for garlands and religious offerings. Leaves used in traditional medicine for sciatica and arthritis.
careTips: Prune after flowering to maintain shape. Protect from frost in northern regions.
storageTips: Flowers are highly perishable. Leaves can be dried and stored for medicinal use.
growthForm: Large shrub or small tree growing up to 10 meters tall
specification: Flowers bloom at night and drop in the morning. Orange flower tubes with white petals create a distinctive appearance.

use: Sweet fruit eaten fresh. Seeds and leaves used in traditional medicine to treat lice and skin conditions.
careTips: Prune to maintain size and shape. Apply mulch to retain moisture. Protect from frost.
storageTips: Ripe fruits can be refrigerated for 2-3 days. Can be frozen as pulp.
growthForm: Small deciduous tree growing up to 6-8 meters tall
specification: Hand pollination may improve fruit set. Seeds are toxic and should not be consumed.

use: Pods used as vegetable. Leaves, flowers, and seeds are edible and highly nutritious. Used in traditional medicine.
careTips: Can be grown as annual or perennial. Prune regularly to promote branching. Protect from frost.
storageTips: Fresh leaves last 3-4 days in refrigeration. Can be dried and powdered for longer storage.
growthForm: Fast-growing deciduous tree up to 12 meters tall
specification: Known as 'Miracle Tree' due to exceptional nutritional content. All parts of the plant are usable and beneficial.

use: Used in religious ceremonies associated with Lord Shiva. Used externally in traditional medicine for pain relief.
careTips: Keep away from children and pets due to high toxicity. Can become invasive in some areas.
storageTips: Not recommended for home storage due to high toxicity.
growthForm: Shrubby annual or short-lived perennial growing up to 1.5 meters tall
specification: Highly toxic if ingested. Contains tropane alkaloids that can cause hallucinations, severe toxicity, and death.

use: Leaves used as spice in Indian cooking. Also used in traditional medicine for digestion and diabetes.
careTips: Protect from frost. Apply balanced fertilizer during growing season. Prune to maintain shape.
storageTips: Dried leaves can be stored in airtight containers for up to a year, away from direct light.
growthForm: Evergreen tree growing up to 20 meters tall
specification: Different from European bay leaf (Laurus nobilis). Has three prominent veins running along the length of the leaf.

use: Seeds used as spice in cooking and for medicinal purposes, particularly for digestive disorders.
waterNeeds: Moderate; keep soil consistently moist until established
careTips: Sow directly in well-draining soil. Thin seedlings to 30 cm apart. Harvest when seeds turn brownish-gray.
storageTips: Store dried seeds in airtight containers in cool, dry place for up to 3 years.
growthForm: Annual herb growing up to 1-1.5 meters tall
specification: Contains thymol which gives it distinctive aroma and medicinal properties. Often used in chutneys and pickles.

use: Popular houseplant believed to bring wealth and prosperity. Also purifies indoor air.
waterNeeds: Moderate; allow top inch of soil to dry between watering
careTips: Grows well in hanging baskets or climbing up moss poles. Prune to control size and promote bushiness.
storageTips: Not applicable for storage; grown as living plant.
growthForm: Evergreen vine with heart-shaped variegated leaves
specification: Mildly toxic if ingested. Can grow up to 20 meters in natural habitat. Easy to propagate from stem cuttings.
